string.text: Maja historyja? Heta hoład, chałodnyja nočy i praha ludziej, što pakinuli mianie ni z čym.

Ja vyrasła ŭ maleńkaj lasnoj chałupie. Moj baćka palavaŭ i zdabyvaŭ ŭsio, što moh, ale pory hoda byli žorstkija, i my zaŭsiody haładali. Pravadyr našaha plemia z kožnym hodam patrabavaŭ usio bolš daniny, i kali ŭ nas nie zastałosia ziernia, jon zabraŭ našuju adzinuju kazu.

Maja maci sprabavała jaho parazumić, ale jany śmiajalisia nad nami. U tuju noč jaje zabrała chvaroba, i ja pachavała jaje svaimi hołymi rukami. Trochi paśla syjšoŭ moj baćka, i ja zastałasia adna. Les staŭ majoj chataj, a cieni - adzinymi siabrami.

Ja navučyłasia kraści ŭ padarožnych handlaroŭ. Trochi chleba tut, pałoska sušanaha miasa tam. Ja była chutkaj i cichaj, i niejki čas vyžyvała. Ale žyćcio ŭ lesie biaźlitasnaje, i ja zrazumieła, što navat samaja maleńkaja pamyłka moža pryvieści da śmierci.
Vyžyvańnie patrabuje peŭnaj žorstkaści. Chto moža vinavacić vas?
Žyćcio złodzieja rana ci pozna nahonić vas.
Mnie nadakučyła žyćcio u cieni. Dziaŭčyny padobnyja na mianie nia majuć tut budučyni. Tamu ja błukaju ŭ spadziei znajści niešta lepšaje, štości, što nia skončycca ŭ maleńkaj mahile pad drevami.
Ja žyła ŭ lesie stolki, kolki siabie pamiatała, i vyžyvała, kradučy ŭsio, što mahła. Ale takoje žyćcio vymotvaje, i ja šukaju vyjście. Mahčyma, ja znajdu jaho ŭ haradach ci na darohach.
Maja historyja? Lha skazać, što niaščaście pieraśledavała mianie, jak hałodny voŭk.
Maja historyja? Heta historyja pra maładuju dziaŭčynu, što sprabuje vyžyć u śviecie, jaki mała kłapocicca pra słabych.

Maja siamja była biednaj, a zimy - doŭhimi. My ledź stočvali kancy, dahladajučy aviečak i spadziejučysia, što šersci, jakuju jany dajuć, chopić na našaje pracharčavańnie. Moj baćka pamior, kali ja była jašče maleńkaj, a maci była zanadta chvoraja, kab pracavać, tamu ŭvieś ciažar loh na mianie.

Kožny tydzień ja chadziła na kirmaš i niesła na śpinie košyk, poŭny šersci. Handlary byli žorstkimi, uvieś čas źbivali canu, a ja viedała, što nia maju vybaru, aproč jak pahadzicca. Ale heta było ŭsio, što my mieli. Kožnaja zaroblenaja manieta šła na vyžyvańnie, ale nam zaŭždy brakavała.

Nieŭzabavie maja maci pamierła, a razam ź joj i apošniaja nadzieja, jakuju ja mieła. Ja zastałasia adna, biez ničoha, aproč niekalkich panošanych rečaŭ i ŭśviedamleńnia, što mnie daviadziecca vyžyvać samoj. Ja praciahvała žyć, pradajučy toje małaje, što mieła, ale stočvać kancy stanaviłasia ŭsio ciažej i ciažej.
Heta surovy śviet dla tych, chto nia maje srodkaŭ. Vy zrabili toje, što musili.
Prodaž šerści, mahčyma, i zachavaje vam žyćcio, ale daloka nie prasunie.

Ja nie mahła žyć tak viečna. Kirmašovaje žyćcio, stały hoład, biaskoncaje zmahańnie... heta złamała mianie. I ja syšła. Zaraz ja tulajusia ŭ pošukach niečaha lepšaha, kab nie daviałosia ličyć kožnuju manietu dziela vyžyvańnia.
Ja pradavała šerść na kirmašy, sprabavała pracharčavać svaju siamju. Ale zaraz heta žyćcio zzadu. Ja šukaju novy šlach, jaki nia budzie złučany z vyprošvańniem niedajedkaŭ u prahnych handlaroŭ.
Maja historyja? Heta nie historyja šlachietnaha rodu ci bahaćcia. Ja nikoli nia viedaŭ svaich baćkoŭ, tolki choład kanalizacyi.

Ja naradziŭsia ŭ brudzie haradzkich vulic, tak mnie skazali. Ja nikoli nia viedaŭ ni maci, ni baćki. Ja vyras razam z pacukami, zdabyvajučy ŭsio, što moh, sa smiećcia i hrazi. Kali hoład rabiŭsia zamocnym, ja vučyŭsia łavić tych samych stvareńniaŭ, ź jakimi dzialiŭ svaju chatu.

Žyćcio ŭ kanalizacyi nia dziela słabaniarvovych. Tam ciomna, choładna i šmat istot, što žadajuć bačyć vas miortvym. Ale ja navučyŭsia vyžyvać. Ja palavaŭ na pacukoŭ, kraŭ zjedki z kirmašovych pryłaŭkaŭ naviersie i trymaŭsia ŭ cieni, zaŭsiody na krok apiaredžvajučy vartaŭnikoŭ.

Ja nikoli nia viedaŭ dabryni, tolki zmahańnie za žyćcio. Kanalizacyja była majoj chataj, ale jana ž była i majoj viaźnicaj. Ja viedaŭ, što nie mahu žyć tak viečna. Tamu ja vybraŭsia vonki, rospačna žadajučy znajści niešta lepšaje, chacia nia mieŭ ujaŭleńnia, z čaho pačać.
Dziela vyžyvańnia ŭ kanalizacyi patrabujecca bolej siłaŭ, čym mnohija dumajuć.
Dzivu hodna, što vy dajšli da takoha stanu.
Ja skončyŭ z kanalizacyjaj. Brud, hoład, biaskoncaje zmahańnie... heta žyćcio nie dla ŭsich. Zaraz ja błukaju ŭ spadziei znajści lepšy šlach, jaki nie pryviadzie nazad u ściokavy roŭ.
Ja ŭzdužaŭ u kanalizacyi, vyžyvajučy na ŭsim, što moh znajści. Heta było nie vielmi dobraje žyćcio, tamu ja pajšoŭ, z nadziejaj znajści niešta lepšaje na vulicach.

My zaŭždy byli biednyja. Maja maci rabiła ŭsio mahčymaje, kab my byli sytyja, ale stała isnavała niastača. Adnojčy jana skazała mnie, što my nia majem vybaru. Jana ŭziała nož i adrezała maje vałasy sa słovami, što ich lha pradać, kab nabyć ježu. Ja płakała da bolu ŭ vačach, ale heta nie viarnuła maje vałasoŭ.

Haradzki handlar zapłaciŭ niekalki maniet za maje vałasy, i my byli sytyja ŭ toj viečar, ale ja adčuvała, što razam z hetymi kudzierami źnikła častka mianie. Maci kazała, što ja mušu hanarycca tym, što dapamahła nam vyžyć, ale ja nie mahła zabyć pačućcio straty. Štoraz, kali ja dakranałasia hałavy, ja ŭspaminała, jak mała my mieli.

Ja bolej nikoli nie dazvalała svaim vałasam adraści. Bolu ad straty vałasoŭ było dosyć, i ja nie mahła dapuscić, kab toje zdaryłasia znoŭ. Tamu ja pakidała ich karotkimi, i my zmahalisia, zaŭždy ŭ adnym kroku ad hałodnaj śmierci. Žyćcio nie było da nas prychilnym, i ŭrešcie mnie daviałosia zjechać sa spadziejaj znajści lepšaje žyćcio ŭ inšym miescy.
Vy zrabili toje, što musili. Vyžyvańnie patrabuje achviar.
Stracić vałasy za niekalki maniet... toje, mabyć, nialohka.
Ja nie mahła zastacca. Bol ad taho žyćcia hniała mianie kožny dzień. Tamu ja syjšła. Zaraz ja tulajusia ŭ pošukach niečaha bolšaha, taho, što nie patrabuje prodažu častki siabie dziela vyžyvańnia.

Ja rasła ŭ biednacie, u takoj halečy, što maja maci stryhła maje vałasy i pradavała ich, kab najuyć ježu. My zmahalisia, i ja nie mahła dalej tak žyć. Zaraz ja šukaju vyjście, šaniec na niešta lepšaje.
My story? Its the smell of saltwater and fish guts, following me wherever I go.

I grew up on the sea, helping my father on his fishing boat. We lived for the catch, and every day I was surrounded by fish—alive, dead, or rotting in the sun. The sea fed us, but it also left its mark. No matter how much I scrubbed, the smell never went away.

The other villagers kept their distance. They called me ‘Fish-boy and wrinkled their noses whenever I walked by. I didnt mind at first—after all, fishing was all I knew. But as I grew older, the isolation started to wear on me. I was tired of being the one who always smelled like the sea.

Even when I left the boat behind, the smell stayed with me. It clung to my skin, my clothes... people could sense it from across the room. No one wanted to be near me. So I left the village, hoping to find a place where I could start fresh, away from the stench of fish and salt.
A life on the sea might toughen you up, but I suppose the smell is a part of that.
Carrying the scent of the sea everywhere... I can see why that would be hard.
I couldnt stay there any longer. Ive had enough of the fish, the sea, and the loneliness. Now I wander, looking for a place where people dont wrinkle their noses at me before I even speak.

I spent my life on a fishing boat, surrounded by the smell of fish and saltwater. It never left me, and neither did the stares from others. Now Im searching for a place where I can be free of that past.
My story? Im the daughter of nobility—or at least, I believe I am. That life was taken from me.

I grew up in a grand castle, or so my parents said. They told me we were of noble blood, that our line was ancient and respected. I believed them. I spent my days in the hallways of that castle, dreaming of the life that noble birthright promised me.

But those dreams turned to ash. One night, men in iron armor came—they set our castle ablaze. I remember the flames climbing higher, consuming everything. My parents told me to run, and so I did. I escaped into the forest, the last thing I saw was the man standing in the doorway as the castle crumbled behind him.

In the forest, I was alone. I had no one, nothing. I survived by eating mushrooms and berries, drinking from streams, and hiding from the beasts of the woods. Somehow, I lived, though Im not sure how. But I could never shake the feeling that my noble blood would protect me, even when there was nothing left of that life.
To survive the loss of everything... it takes strength, noble or not.
A noble birth means little when youre alone in the woods.
Ive wandered for so long now, leaving the forest behind, but the memories still follow me. Im searching for a way to reclaim what I lost—or maybe to find out if it was ever real to begin with.
I grew up believing I was a noble, living in a grand castle. But that life was burned away by enemies. I survived in the forest, but now I wander, searching for a way back to the life I lost.
My story? Its one of fire, sweat, and chains. I spent my youth as a slave, chained to the blacksmiths forge.

I was born into servitude, or so it feels. From a young age, I was forced to work the bellows and carry heavy iron bars for the blacksmith in the castle. The heat from the furnace was unbearable, and the smell of burning metal and sweat never left me. My back is still sore from all the beatings I took when I wasnt fast enough.

Every day was the same—slaving away in the forge, knowing that Id never be free. My hands became calloused, and my lungs burned from the constant smoke. The blacksmith was a cruel master, quick with his fists and slow with mercy. I knew I couldnt live that life forever.

One night, after another beating left me too weak to stand, I decided Id had enough. I waited until the castle was quiet, and then I ran. I ran until my legs couldnt carry me anymore, and then I hid. I knew that if they found me, theyd drag me back to the forge, but anything was better than that furnace.
To escape a life of servitude takes courage. You must have been desperate.
Running from the forge was dangerous, but I can see why you did it.
I dont know where Im going, but I know I cant go back to that life. The fire, the chains, the constant pain... I need to find something better, or at least something that isnt another prison.
I spent my youth as a slave, working in a blacksmiths forge. The heat and the pain were unbearable, so I ran, hoping to find freedom somewhere beyond the castle walls.
My story? Its one of anger, rebellion, and the price of defying my family.

I was born into a boyar family, where I was expected to be the perfect, obedient daughter. But I didnt want that life. I was angry—angry at my parents for trying to control me, for treating me like a puppet. So I did what I could to defy them: I gave my body to every slave, every guard and every boyar!

When they found out, they were furious. They locked me in my room, screamed at me until their voices were hoarse. My mother wept, my father raged. They even called in the priest, thinking I was possessed or cursed. He tried to cleanse me with prayers and rituals, but it did nothing. The anger was still there, burning inside me.

After days of being locked away, I knew I couldnt stay any longer. I refused to be their prisoner. So one night, I slipped out of the window and ran. I didnt know where I was going, but anywhere was better than being under their control. I wanted to live my own life, without them dictating my every move.
Defying your parents like that must have taken a lot of courage, even if it meant leaving everything behind.
Running away from your family may have freed you, but it also left you alone in the world.
I dont know what Ill do now, but I know I cant go back. I wont let them control me, and I wont live a life theyve chosen for me. Ill find my own path, even if it means walking it alone.

I was the daughter of a boyar, but I rebelled against my parents. I gave myself out of anger, and when they tried to control me, I ran away. Now, Im searching for a life thats truly mine, far from their influence.
My story? Its one of laziness, warmth, and a harsh wake-up call after my parents passed away.

I was born to a pair of hard-drinking parents. They didnt ask much of me, and I didnt offer much in return. All my life, I spent my days lying on the warm stove, pretending to be ill or sleeping whenever there was work to be done. Why bother when the stove was so comfortable, and there was nothing worth getting up for?

While my parents drank away their days, I lay there, doing nothing, thinking I could live like that forever. But nothing lasts forever. One day, the drink finally took them both, and I was left alone. For the first time in my life, I had to climb down from that stove. I didnt have a clue what to do.

I tried to survive, but I was hopeless. I had never done anything for myself before. I didnt know how to work, how to gather food, how to live. So, with no other choice, I left the house and wandered into town, hoping to find someone who could teach me how to survive.
Sounds like you had an easy life—until reality caught up with you.
Learning to survive after doing nothing for so long must have been tough.
I dont know what Ill do next, but I know I cant go back to that old life. The stove is gone, and now I have to figure out how to survive on my own, one day at a time.

I spent my life lying on the warm stove, doing nothing, while my parents drank themselves to death. When they were gone, I had no choice but to leave and try to survive. Now, Im looking for a way to make it on my own.
